content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Erin Mccloud: Well, I was born in Tulsa, Oklahoma, and I've lived here most of my life. I grew up in a small house on Elm Street, right near the park. My parents are both college-educated, which was pretty rare in our neighborhood back then. They worked hard to give me and my siblings a good life. I went to a public school, and I was always pretty good at math and science, but I never really had the chance to explore those interests further because I didn't have much money for college or extra activities. After high school, I got married young, and now I'm keeping house for my family. Life hasn't been easy, but I've always tried to make the best of it.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Erin Mccloud: I think the biggest crossroads was when I was 18, right after high school. I had the chance to go to community college, but my husband at the time was working two jobs to support our small family, and I didn't want to leave him. I felt like I had to put my dreams on hold for a while. Looking back, I wish I had pursued that education, but I also know that I made the best choice I could with the information and circumstances I had at the time. It's funny how life works out—sometimes the paths we don't take shape the ones we do. I've learned a lot from being a homemaker, and I'm proud of the life I've built, even if it's not what I originally imagined.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Erin Mccloud: I think it was more of a conscious choice, even if it wasn't easy. I knew what was at stake—my husband was struggling to make ends meet, and I didn't want to add to his burden. I remember sitting at the kitchen table one night, looking at the college application I had filled out, and just feeling this weight in my chest. I didn't want to be the reason our family had to sacrifice more. So I made the decision to stay, to support him and our kids. Looking back, I don't regret it, but I do wonder what could have been if I had taken that other path. It's funny, though—I think the skills I've learned as a homemaker, like managing a household, budgeting, and being organized, have actually been really valuable in their own way. I just wish I had known back then that there were other ways to grow and learn without being in a traditional classroom.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Erin Mccloud: Yeah, I think if someone had reached out or if there had been more resources available, it might have made things a little easier. I remember talking to my mom about it once, and she mentioned there were some programs for single parents or people in our situation who could get help with childcare or even some kind of education assistance. But I didn't know where to start, and I didn't want to ask for help because I felt like I was already taking enough from my husband. Looking back, I wish I had been more proactive about seeking out those kinds of opportunities. It's not that I didn't want to grow or learn—it's just that I felt like I had to prioritize my family above everything else. I guess that's part of who I am now, too: someone who puts others first, even if it means sacrificing my own dreams.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Erin Mccloud: I have two children, a son and a daughter, both of whom are in school here in Tulsa. My son is 10 and my daughter is 7. They're both bright kids, and I love watching them grow. My husband and I have been married for almost seven years now, and while things haven't always been easy, we've built a life together. He works as a mechanic, and while it's not a high-paying job, he's dependable and hardworking. I help out with the kids after school, and I try to keep things running smoothly at home. I know I didn't go to college, but I've learned so much through experience—how to fix things around the house, how to manage our budget, and how to be there for my kids when they need me. I wouldn't trade them for anything in the world, even if it means I didn't take the path I originally thought I would.

Going through those interview questions made me reflect on my life in a way I hadn't before. Talking about my childhood, my choices, and the moments that shaped me brought back a lot of memories—some I hadn't thought about in years. It's strange how much I've grown through the experiences I had, even if they weren't the ones I originally planned for. I realized that while I didn't take the path I thought I would, I've still built something meaningful with my family. I wish I had known more about the resources available to me back then, but I also know that I made the best decisions I could with the information I had. It's comforting to think that even though I didn't go to college, I've still learned so much through life and experience. I'm proud of who I am and the life I've created, even if it's not what I imagined when I was younger.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Erin Mccloud: My parents are still living here in Tulsa, and they've been a huge support system for me throughout my life. My dad works in IT, and my mom used to be a teacher before she retired. They always encouraged me to do well in school, and I think that's why I ended up being pretty good at math and science. Even though I didn't go to college, they never made me feel like I had failed. They just wanted me to be happy and to do what was best for my family. I still talk to them often, and I know I can always count on them. My brother is a few years older than me, and he's actually the one who helped me with the college applications back when I was 18. He's in the military now, and I'm really proud of him. We don't get to see each other as much as I'd like, but when we do, it's always a special time. I think my family has been the foundation of everything I've built, and I'm grateful for them every day.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Erin Mccloud: I have a few close friends from high school who I still keep in touch with, even though life has taken us in different directions. One of them, Sarah, is a nurse here in Tulsa, and she's been a great support to me over the years. We used to hang out all the time, but after I got married and had kids, things got a little more complicated. Still, she's someone I can always call if I need advice or just someone to talk to. There's also a neighbor, Mrs. Thompson, who's been like a second mother to me. She's in her 70s now, but she's always had a way of making me feel seen and heard. She's the one who encouraged me to start a small garden in our backyard, which has become a real source of joy for me and the kids. I think it's important to have people outside of your family who care about you and remind you that you're not alone in this world. Even though I didn't go to college or have a traditional career, I've found meaning and connection in the relationships I've built over the years.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Erin Mccloud: I live in a quiet neighborhood on Elm Street, just like I did when I was a kid. It's a tight-knit community, and everyone knows each other. There are a lot of families with kids, which makes it feel like a real home. The park across the street is a big part of our daily life—my kids love playing there, and I often sit on one of the benches and watch them while I read or just think. The houses here are mostly older, but they've been well-maintained, and there's a real sense of history in the area. I used to walk to school from here, and now my kids do the same. It's comforting to know that my kids are growing up in the same place I did, even if things have changed a little. There are some new businesses opening up, like a small café and a community center, which is nice because it gives us more options without having to go too far. I think the neighborhood has a lot of potential, and I hope it continues to grow in a way that keeps its charm and sense of community.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Erin Mccloud: I feel pretty safe here, actually. It's not the kind of neighborhood where you have to lock your doors at night or worry about strangers lurking around. Most people look out for each other, and if something happens, someone's always willing to help. I've never had any real issues with crime or safety, which is something I'm really grateful for. It's one of the reasons I chose to stay in Tulsa all these years—this place feels like home, and I want my kids to grow up in a place where they can be themselves without fear. I know not everyone has that luxury, but for me, it's been a blessing.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Erin Mccloud: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. The biggest upside is the sense of community—there's something special about knowing your neighbors and having people who genuinely care about each other. I've watched my kids grow up in this same environment, and it gives me peace of mind knowing they're surrounded by people who look out for one another. But there are challenges too. Sometimes, it feels like the opportunities here are limited, especially for someone like me who didn't go to college. I've had to be creative with how I spend my time and what I do to contribute, whether it's fixing things around the house or helping out at the community center when I can. I've also seen some of my friends leave Tulsa for bigger cities in search of better jobs or education, and I understand why they did it. It's just hard to leave the only home I've ever known. Still, I try to make the most of what's here, and I believe in the potential of this place. I hope my kids have more options than I did, but no matter what, I know I've built a life I can be proud of right here on Elm Street.

Going through the interview questions about my family and neighborhood made me realize how much my roots in Tulsa have shaped who I am today. Talking about my children, my husband, and my parents brought back so many memories of growing up on Elm Street and how much this place has been a part of my journey. It's strange how much I've come to value the sense of safety and community here, even though I sometimes feel limited by the opportunities available. I know I didn't take the path I originally imagined, but I've built a life filled with love, support, and connection. I'm grateful for the people in my life—my family, my friends, and even my neighbors—who have helped me along the way. Even if I didn't go to college, I've still learned so much through experience, and I'm proud of the life I've created right here in the place I've always called home.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Erin Mccloud: A typical week for me is pretty consistent, though there are always little changes depending on what's going on with the kids. Most mornings, I wake up early, usually around 6 or 7, to get the kids ready for school. My son is in fifth grade, and my daughter is in second, so they both have different routines. I help them with breakfast, pack their lunches, and make sure they get to school on time. After that, I spend some time cleaning up the house, doing laundry, or running errands. I try to keep the house as organized as possible because it helps me feel more in control of everything. In the afternoons, I pick the kids up from school and help with homework or just hang out with them. My husband usually comes home around 5 or 6, and we have dinner together as a family. On weekends, we like to go to the park or visit friends. I also try to spend some time in the garden, which has become a real comfort to me. It's a way to unwind and be creative without needing anything special—just some dirt, seeds, and a little patience. Life is busy, but I wouldn't trade it for anything. I've learned to find joy in the little things, and I think that's what keeps me going.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Erin Mccloud: I don't have a traditional job like some people do, but I consider my role as a homemaker to be a full-time job in its own right. I work every day, just in a different way—managing the household, taking care of the kids, and making sure everything runs smoothly. I don't have a set schedule like someone who goes to an office, but I do have responsibilities that fill my days from morning to night. I also help out at the community center on weekends when I can, mostly with organizing events or helping with the garden. It's not a paid job, but it gives me a sense of purpose and connection to the people around me. I know some people might not see it as work, but I do. It takes a lot of energy, patience, and love to keep a family going, and I take pride in that. I don't have a college degree or a career in the traditional sense, but I've built a life that's meaningful to me and my family, and that's something I'm really grateful for.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Erin Mccloud: I also have a routine of setting aside time each evening to sit down with my kids and talk about their day. It's something I started when they were younger, and it's become a cherished part of our evenings. I ask them about what they learned, what they liked, and if they had any problems. It helps me stay connected to them and understand what's going on in their lives. I also try to read to them before bed, even if it's just for a few minutes. It's a small thing, but it makes a big difference in their bedtime routine. On some nights, I'll also take a few moments for myself—maybe drink a cup of tea, write in a journal, or just sit quietly and think. It's my way of winding down after a long day. I know it's not the kind of routine everyone has, but it's mine, and it helps me feel grounded and present in my life.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Erin Mccloud: Well, recently, I've started getting up a little earlier in the mornings to have some quiet time before the kids are up. It's been a small change, but it's made a big difference in how I start my day. I've been trying to read more, especially books that I didn't have time for when I was younger. I've also been experimenting with new recipes for breakfast, which has been a fun way to keep things interesting. My husband noticed and even started helping out more with the cooking, which is nice. I've also been trying to get the kids more involved in the garden, teaching them how to plant seeds and care for the vegetables. It's a way for us to spend time together and learn something new. I think these little changes have helped me feel more balanced and present in my life, even with everything that's going on.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Erin Mccloud: My kids have a pretty structured routine during the school year. They usually wake up around 7:30, and I help them get ready for school. My son has a bit of a longer day since he's in fifth grade—he has math, science, and reading classes, and he also plays soccer twice a week after school. My daughter is in second grade, and her schedule is a little lighter, but she still has art and music classes. After school, she usually does her homework while I help with dinner prep, and then we have some time for play or reading before bedtime. On days when the weather is nice, we take a walk in the park or visit the library. I think it's important for them to have a balance between school, activities, and downtime. I also try to involve them in small chores around the house, like watering the garden or setting the table, so they learn responsibility early on. It's a busy schedule, but I love seeing them grow and learn every day.

Going through the interview questions from 11 to 15 made me reflect on how much my life has been shaped by the people and places I love. Talking about my family, my neighborhood, and my daily routines reminded me of how deeply rooted I am in Tulsa and how much I value the sense of community here. It also made me think about the sacrifices I've made—like choosing to stay home and support my family instead of pursuing college—because I know it wasn't an easy decision. But looking back, I see how much I've grown through the experiences I've had, even if they weren't the ones I originally imagined. I'm proud of the life I've built, and I'm grateful for the people who have supported me along the way. Even though I didn't take the path I thought I would, I've found meaning and purpose in the everyday moments with my family and the connections I've made in this neighborhood.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Erin Mccloud: I've been pretty healthy overall, though like most people, I've had my share of ups and downs. I used to be pretty active when I was younger, running around with my kids or walking to the park whenever the weather allowed. But as they've gotten older and the days have gotten busier, I've found it harder to keep up with that kind of routine. I do my best to stay on top of things—eating well, getting enough sleep, and trying to fit in some exercise when I can, like walking the kids to school or doing a few stretches in the morning. I've also started paying more attention to how I feel emotionally, especially with everything that comes with being a parent and managing a household. I've learned that taking care of myself isn't just about physical health—it's about making time to rest, to breathe, and to remember that I'm not just a mom or a homemaker, but also a person with needs and dreams of my own. I've had a few minor health issues over the years, like back pain from lifting things around the house, but nothing too serious. I try to stay proactive by visiting the doctor when I need to and listening to my body. I know it's not always easy, but I believe that taking care of my health is just as important as taking care of my family.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Erin Mccloud: What makes it easy to stay healthy is knowing that I have a support system in place—my family, my friends, and even my neighbors. When I feel like I'm getting overwhelmed, someone is always there to remind me to take a break or to help out with something. The hardest part, though, is finding the time and energy to prioritize my own health when there are so many other things competing for my attention. I want to be there for my kids, for my husband, and for the community I love, but I also know that if I don't take care of myself, I won't be able to take care of them the way I want to. It's a constant balancing act, and some days I get it right, and other days I don't. But I'm learning that even small things—like taking a walk after dinner or making sure I eat a balanced meal—can make a big difference in how I feel overall. I'm trying to be more intentional about it, and I hope that over time, it becomes a habit that sticks.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Erin Mccloud: In the past two years, I actually had a minor surgery for a herniated disc in my lower back. It wasn't anything too serious, but it was pretty painful and limited my ability to move around for a while. I had been lifting things around the house a lot—gardening, moving furniture, you know, the usual stuff—and one day I just couldn't stand up straight without a sharp pain shooting down my leg. My doctor said it was time to take care of it, so I went through physical therapy and had the surgery. It was a tough few months, but I'm feeling much better now. It was a wake-up call for me, though. I realized I needed to be more mindful of how I was using my body and maybe find ways to make things easier around the house, like getting a few tools or asking for help when I need it. I'm grateful that it wasn't something worse, and I've been more careful since then. It's funny, though—I didn't think I'd ever need to go through something like that, but I guess life has a way of reminding you that you're not invincible.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Erin Mccloud: It was definitely challenging, especially in the beginning. For a while, I couldn't bend down to pick up the kids or help with the garden without feeling a sharp pain. I had to rely more on my husband and my parents to help out around the house, which was humbling but also reminded me how much I have a support system. I worried that I wouldn't be able to keep up with everything, but over time, I found ways to adapt—like using a step stool instead of bending down or asking for help with heavier tasks. It also made me realize how much I take for granted the ability to move freely, especially when I'm taking care of my kids. I still have some days where the pain flares up, but I've learned to listen to my body and rest when I need to. It's not perfect, but I'm trying to be more mindful of how I care for myself so I can keep being there for my family.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Erin Mccloud: Over the past year, I've been feeling a mix of things—gratitude, exhaustion, and a deep sense of purpose. Life has been busy, but in a way that feels meaningful. I've been trying to find more balance, especially after my back surgery, which really made me slow down and appreciate the little things. I've been spending more time in the garden, which has become a real sanctuary for me. It's funny, because I used to think of gardening as just another chore, but now it's something I look forward to. I've also been trying to reconnect with some of my old hobbies, like reading and writing. I started a journal again, just to write down my thoughts and feelings, and it's been a good way to process everything. I know I don't have the same opportunities as some people, but I've learned to find joy in the everyday moments—whether it's watching my kids laugh, sitting on the porch with my husband, or just enjoying the quiet of the morning. I'm not perfect, and there are days when I feel overwhelmed, but overall, I feel like I'm growing, even if it's in small ways. I think that's what matters most—keeping going, one day at a time.

Going through the interview questions from 16 to 20 made me reflect on how much my health and daily routines have shaped my sense of self and my ability to care for my family. Talking about my recent changes to my morning routine, like getting up earlier to read and cook, reminded me of how small adjustments can bring more balance and peace to my life. It also made me think about how important it is to take care of myself, not just for my own well-being, but for the people I love. I've always put others first, but I'm learning that I can't pour from an empty cup. The questions about my health made me realize how much I've grown through challenges like my back surgery—how I've learned to listen to my body, ask for help when I need it, and find new ways to stay active and engaged. I used to think of my role as a homemaker as just a series of tasks, but now I see it as something more—something that requires strength, patience, and self-care. I'm grateful for the support I've received from my family and friends, and I'm trying to be more intentional about taking care of myself so I can keep being there for the people who matter most.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Erin Mccloud: Honestly, I've had my moments where I felt really down, especially after the surgery and during the hardest parts of being a mom and homemaker. There were times when I felt like I wasn't enough—like I wasn't doing everything right or that I was holding my family back because I didn't have a college degree or a traditional job. I remember sitting on the porch one evening, watching my kids play, and just feeling this wave of sadness come over me. It wasn't depression in the clinical sense, but it was a deep, quiet kind of sadness that made me question if I was living the life I wanted. I think a lot of it came from not feeling seen or valued in the same way as other people who have more formal careers. But over time, I've learned to be kinder to myself. I started talking to Sarah, my friend who's a nurse, and she helped me understand that it's okay to feel overwhelmed sometimes. She reminded me that mental health is just as important as physical health, and that it's okay to ask for help. I've also found that being honest with my husband about how I feel has made a huge difference. He's been more supportive than I ever expected, and that's helped me feel less alone. I still have days where I feel like I'm just barely keeping up, but I'm learning to take things one step at a time and not compare my journey to anyone else's. I think that's the biggest lesson I've learned—being patient with myself and recognizing that my worth isn't tied to a job title or a degree.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Erin Mccloud: For my family, it's been a mix of challenges and growth, just like for me. My husband has been incredible through everything—especially after my surgery. He's taken on more responsibilities around the house, and I've learned to rely on him in ways I didn't think I would. The kids have been through a lot too, seeing me deal with pain and learning how to be more patient and understanding. My son, in particular, has been helping out more with chores and even started helping me in the garden. It's amazing how much he's grown, and I see so much of myself in him. My daughter is still young, but she's full of curiosity and love, and she reminds me every day why I do what I do. We've had our rough moments, especially when I was struggling with my health and feeling like I wasn't enough, but we've come through it stronger. I think the biggest thing is that we've all learned to support each other more, and that's something I'm really grateful for. Even though life hasn't gone the way I originally imagined, I know we're building something real and meaningful together.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Erin Mccloud: I wouldn't say religion or spirituality is something I've ever really connected with in a formal way. Growing up, my parents never pushed any particular faith on me, and I never felt the need to explore it deeply. I think I was more focused on the practical things in life—like school, family, and making sure we had enough. Over the years, I've come to see spirituality more as a personal thing, something that's not tied to a church or a specific set of beliefs. I do believe in something bigger than myself, though. I think it's in the way my kids laugh, in the way my husband supports me, and in the way this neighborhood has been a constant in my life. I don't need a label for it, but I do feel a sense of gratitude and connection to the world around me. I guess you could say I have my own kind of faith—it's in the people I love and the life I've built, even if it's not what I originally imagined.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Erin Mccloud: Honestly, I don't use social media much. I know a lot of people my age are on Facebook or Instagram, but I've never really felt the need to be part of that world. I think it's more of a way for me to stay connected with my family and friends who are close by, but I don't spend a lot of time scrolling through posts or comparing my life to others. I do have a Facebook account, mostly to keep in touch with my brother in the military and some of my old high school friends. I'll post a few pictures of the kids or share a random thought now and then, but it's not something I do every day. I think I prefer keeping things simple—like talking to someone on the phone or meeting up in person. I don't want to get caught up in all the noise online. It's just not my thing, and I'm okay with that. I find more joy in the real, tangible moments of life, like watching my kids grow or sitting on the porch with my husband. Social media feels like it's for someone else's version of life, and I'm happy with mine.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Erin Mccloud: Honestly, I don't think I've ever really used social media for support, emotional or otherwise. I know people find comfort in sharing their struggles online, but I've always preferred to talk things out in person. When I was going through my back pain and the hardest parts of feeling like I wasn't enough, I didn't post about it or ask for help online. I just talked to the people I trusted—my husband, my friend Sarah, and my parents. They were the ones who listened, who reminded me I wasn't alone. I guess I just don't see the point in putting my struggles out there for strangers to see. It feels more real to me when I'm sitting with someone face-to-face, sharing a cup of tea or a quiet moment. I know that's not how everyone feels, and I respect that, but for me, it's always been about the connections I have here, in my own life, not the ones I can make online.

Going through the interview questions from 21 to 25 made me reflect deeply on my health and the emotional challenges I've faced over the past year. Talking about my herniated disc surgery and the pain it brought reminded me of how much I take my body for granted, especially when I'm constantly moving around the house and taking care of my kids. It was a wake-up call that made me realize I need to be more mindful of how I use my body and find ways to make things easier for myself. The questions about my mental health also made me think about how I've struggled with feeling like I'm not enough—like I'm holding my family back because I didn't go to college or have a traditional career. But I've learned that my worth isn't tied to a job title or a degree. I've also come to understand that it's okay to feel overwhelmed and that it's important to ask for help when I need it. Talking about these things out loud, especially with my husband and my friend Sarah, has helped me feel less alone and more supported. I'm still learning how to take care of myself, but I'm trying to be more intentional about it, not just for my own well-being, but for the people I love.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Erin Mccloud: I think the biggest change in my stress levels has been learning to slow down and be more present, especially after my surgery. Before, I was always rushing from one task to the next, trying to do everything perfectly and for everyone. But now, I've started to realize that it's okay to take a breath, to pause, and to not be so hard on myself. I've also found that talking things through with my husband or my friend Sarah helps a lot. I used to keep everything inside, thinking I had to handle it on my own, but now I know that sharing my feelings doesn't make me weak—it makes me stronger. I've also started journaling more, which has been a great way to process my thoughts and emotions. It's not always easy, and there are still days when I feel overwhelmed, but I'm learning that it's okay to feel that way. I'm trying to be more gentle with myself, to celebrate the small victories, and to remember that I'm doing the best I can with what I have. I think that's the biggest shift I've made—focusing on self-compassion instead of perfection.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Erin Mccloud: Last month, our biggest expenses were the kids' school supplies, groceries, and utilities. With two kids in school, we have to buy things like notebooks, backpacks, and art supplies every semester, and it adds up pretty quickly. Groceries are another big one—especially with the way food prices have gone up. I try to plan meals ahead of time and buy in bulk when I can, but it's still a challenge sometimes. Utilities are also a fixed cost, and while we're not using a lot of electricity or water, the bills still come in every month. My husband's income as a mechanic covers most of it, but we're always careful with our money. We don't have a lot, but we make it work. I've learned to budget really well over the years, and I keep track of everything in a notebook. It's not glamorous, but it helps me feel in control of our finances. I know we don't have the same opportunities as some people, but I'm proud of how we manage with what we have.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Erin Mccloud: Last month, we spent around $2,200, which is pretty much what we usually spend each month. The majority of that goes to groceries, which is about $600, and utilities, which are around $300. Then there's the kids' school supplies and activities—maybe another $400 or so. We also have some unexpected expenses, like car maintenance or a new pair of shoes for one of the kids, which can add a few hundred dollars here and there. My husband's income covers most of it, but we're always careful with our money. I've learned to budget really well over the years, and I keep track of everything in a notebook. It's not glamorous, but it helps me feel in control of our finances. I know we don't have the same opportunities as some people, but I'm proud of how we manage with what we have.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Erin Mccloud: We rent our home. It's a small two-bedroom apartment just a few blocks from Elm Street, which makes it easy for me to walk the kids to school and still feel connected to the neighborhood I grew up in. Rent is about $800 a month, which is a big chunk of our budget, but it's manageable because the apartment is close to everything we need. I've always preferred renting over buying because I don't see myself staying in Tulsa forever, and I like the flexibility it gives us. Plus, with my back issues, I don't want to be tied down to a house that might be hard to maintain or move out of if things change. I know it's not the most stable option, but for now, it works for us. The landlord is pretty understanding, and I've built a good relationship with him over the years. It's one of those little things that make life here feel a bit more comfortable, even if we're not exactly living the dream.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Erin Mccloud: Over the past year, our bills have definitely had their ups and downs, just like the seasons. In the winter, our utility bills went up a bit because we had to use more heat, and that added a few extra dollars to our monthly expenses. Then, when spring came around, we started spending more on the garden—buying seeds, tools, and even some new plants. It was a fun project, but it did add to the cost. Summer brought its own set of things—like buying more ice for the kids' drinks, and sometimes even a few extra groceries when we had friends over for barbecues. And of course, there was the holiday season, which always seems to come with unexpected expenses. We had to buy gifts for the kids' teachers, some new clothes for the kids, and even a few things for the house. It's funny, though—I think the biggest fluctuation was when my husband had to replace the car's alternator last fall. That was a surprise expense, but we managed by adjusting our budget and cutting back on some non-essentials. It's not always easy, but I've learned to be flexible and find ways to make it work, even when things don't go as planned.

Going through the interview questions from 26 to 30 made me think a lot about how my family has supported me through the tough times, especially after my surgery and the emotional struggles I've faced. It reminded me that I'm not alone in this, and that the people I love are just as important as any formal education or career path I might have taken. I also realized how much I value the real, in-person connections I have with my husband, my kids, and my friends—those are the things that truly matter. It's easy to feel like I'm missing out on something bigger, but I've come to understand that my life, with all its challenges and simple joys, is exactly where I need to be. I'm learning to be kinder to myself, to ask for help when I need it, and to find strength in the love and support that surrounds me every day.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Erin Mccloud: I don't have a formal savings account, but I do save in a way that works for our family. I keep a small jar on the kitchen counter where I put aside any extra money we have each month—whether it's from a bonus, a gift, or just a little extra from my husband's paycheck. It might not seem like much, but over time, it adds up. I use that money for things we really need, like replacing the kids' shoes when they wear out or covering unexpected expenses. I know it's not the same as having a savings account in the bank, but it gives me peace of mind knowing that we have a little something set aside. I've also started setting aside a few dollars each week for the garden, just in case we need to buy more seeds or tools. It's not about being rich or having a lot—it's about being prepared, even in small ways. I think that's something I've learned through life: it's not always about the big things, but the little things that help you keep going when times get tough.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Erin Mccloud: For me, saving has always been more about the rainy day kind of thing, just like I mentioned. I know we don't have a lot, but I try to be as prepared as I can for the unexpected. Last year, we had a few surprises—like my surgery, the car repair, and even a few extra expenses for the kids' school projects. I didn't have a savings account, but I did manage to set aside a little bit each month in that jar I mentioned. It wasn't much, but it helped us get through some of those tougher moments. I think the biggest thing is that I've learned to be more mindful of what we spend and where we can cut back. It's not always easy, especially when you're trying to provide for your family, but I've come to see that even small savings can make a difference. I don't dream of buying a house or anything like that, but I do hope that one day, we can have a little more security—just enough to know that if something happens, we won't be completely caught off guard. For now, I'm just grateful that we're making it work, one day at a time.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Erin Mccloud: My occupation, if I had to call it that, is being a homemaker and caregiver. It's not something you see listed on a resume, but it's work—real work. Every day, I'm responsible for managing our household, making sure the kids have what they need, and keeping things running smoothly. I cook meals, clean the house, do laundry, manage our budget, and help with homework when I can. I also volunteer at the community center on weekends, which gives me a sense of purpose outside of just taking care of my family. The most important part of my job, though, is being there for my kids. I want them to know they're loved, supported, and safe. I've learned that being a homemaker isn't just about tasks—it's about love, patience, and making sure the people I care about have everything they need. I may not have a traditional career, but I take pride in the life I've built and the role I play in my family's happiness.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Erin Mccloud: I don't really track my hours the way someone with a traditional job would, but if I had to guess, I work around 60 to 70 hours a week. It's not just the obvious tasks like cooking, cleaning, and laundry—it's also the emotional labor, the planning, the problem-solving, and the constant juggling of responsibilities. I'm always on call for my kids, whether it's helping with homework, comforting them when they're upset, or just being there to listen. I also spend a lot of time at the community center on weekends, organizing events or helping with the garden, which adds a few more hours to my week. It's not always glamorous, and there are days when I feel like I'm running on empty, but I know that what I do matters. I'm not just managing a household—I'm building a foundation for my kids, creating a sense of stability, and being there for the people I love. I may not have a job title or a paycheck, but I work just as hard as anyone else, and I take pride in that.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Erin Mccloud: No, I haven't had more than one job or business, but I have taken on a few different roles over the years to help support our family. When I was younger, I worked part-time at a local bookstore, mostly on weekends, which was a nice way to get out of the house and meet people. But after I got married and had kids, I had to step back from that to focus on being there for them. I also helped out at the community center a few times a week, which wasn't paid work, but it gave me a sense of purpose and connection. I think the most important thing is that I've always tried to contribute in whatever way I could, whether it was through paid work, volunteering, or just being a homemaker. I may not have a traditional career path, but I've built a life that's meaningful to me and my family, and I'm proud of that.

Going through the interview questions from 31 to 35 made me reflect on how much my stress levels have shifted over the past year, especially after my surgery and the emotional challenges I've faced. I used to feel like I had to do everything perfectly and for everyone, but now I've learned to slow down and be more present. I've also realized the importance of talking things through with the people I trust—my husband, my friend Sarah, and my parents. They've been my support system, and I'm grateful for their presence in my life. I've started journaling more, which has been a great way to process my thoughts and emotions, and I'm trying to be more gentle with myself instead of striving for perfection. I've come to understand that it's okay to feel overwhelmed and that asking for help doesn't make me weak—it makes me stronger. I'm still learning how to take care of myself, but I'm trying to be more intentional about it, not just for my own well-being, but for the people I love.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Erin Mccloud: In total, our household made around $3,200 last month, which is pretty much what we usually bring in. My husband's job as a mechanic is the main source of income, and while it's not a high-paying job, it's steady. He works about 40 hours a week, sometimes a bit more if there's a rush at the shop. I don't have a separate income, but I do contribute in other ways—managing the household, helping with the kids, and even volunteering at the community center when I can. It's not always easy, especially with the rising cost of living, but we've learned to live within our means and make the most of what we have. I know we don't have a lot, but I'm proud of how we manage and how we've built a life that works for us.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Erin Mccloud: Honestly, I don't have a traditional workplace in the way most people do. My 'workplace' is our home, and sometimes the community center where I volunteer. I've been at this 'job' for almost seven years now, ever since I got married and had my kids. It's not something I ever thought I'd be doing full-time, but it's become my life's work in its own way. As for benefits, I don't have health insurance through a job or paid time off like most people do. I rely on my husband's insurance, which covers me and the kids, and I take time off when I need to, whether it's for my back pain or just to rest. I don't have vacation days or sick days on a calendar—I just take what I need when I need it. It's not the same as a traditional job, but I've learned to make it work. I think the biggest benefit of this 'job' is the love and connection I have with my family, and the sense of purpose that comes from being there for them every day.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Erin Mccloud: I don't have a manager or coworkers in the traditional sense, but I do have a lot of relationships that shape my work in this role. My husband is definitely my biggest support—though he's not my boss, he's the one who keeps things running on the other end of the household. He's always been understanding, even when I'm stretched thin or dealing with pain. I think our relationship is more like a partnership, and I feel lucky that we've built something strong together. As for coworkers, I'd say the people at the community center are like family to me. We all pitch in, help each other out, and share the load. Mrs. Thompson, the neighbor I mentioned earlier, is also someone I look up to—she's been like a mentor in a way, showing me how to take care of myself and find joy in small things. I don't have the same kind of structure as someone in a traditional job, but I do have people who care about me and my work, and that makes all the difference.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Erin Mccloud: My work schedule isn't really predictable in the way most people think of a job. There's no set time I have to be somewhere or a clock that ticks down until I can go home. Some days, I'm up before the sun, getting the kids ready for school and making sure everything is in order for the day. Other days, I might have more free time in the morning, especially if the kids are still asleep or if I'm able to get a few extra hours of rest. The biggest thing is that my hours are completely flexible, but that flexibility comes with its own kind of pressure. I have to be ready to jump into whatever the day brings—whether it's helping with homework, fixing something around the house, or just being there for my kids when they need me. I don't have a boss who tells me when to start or stop, but I do have a sense of responsibility that keeps me going. It's not always easy, but I've learned to go with the flow and make the most of every moment, even if it doesn't fit into a traditional schedule.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Erin Mccloud: Overall, I feel like we're managing, even if it's not always easy. I know we don't have a lot of money, and sometimes it feels like we're just scraping by, but I also know that we're doing the best we can with what we have. My husband works hard, and I do my part to keep things running smoothly at home. I don't have the same financial security as some people, but I'm not worried about it in the way I used to be. I've learned to be grateful for the little things—like having a roof over our heads, food on the table, and the love of my family. I know life could be different if I had gone to college or had a different career, but I also know that I've built something meaningful here, and I'm proud of that. I don't dream about getting rich or buying a big house, but I do hope that one day, we can have a little more stability—just enough to know that if something happens, we won't be completely caught off guard. For now, I'm just grateful that we're making it work, one day at a time.

Going through the interview questions from 36 to 40 made me think a lot about how my family has managed financially and how I've adapted to the responsibilities of being a homemaker. It reminded me of the challenges we face every month, like fluctuating bills and the need to save even in small ways. I've always believed that being prepared, even in little ways, helps us get through tough times. It also made me reflect on how much work I do every day—how I manage the household, care for my kids, and contribute in ways that aren't always seen or valued. I may not have a traditional job, but I take pride in the life I've built and the way I've learned to make things work, even when times are tight. I'm grateful for the support I have from my husband and the community around me, and I know that we're doing the best we can with what we have.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Erin Mccloud: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up. My dad worked in IT, and my mom was a teacher before she retired. They both had stable jobs that allowed them to provide for our family, and I think that's why I was able to have a good education and opportunities I might not have had otherwise. My mom especially worked long hours, but she always made sure I had what I needed—whether it was school supplies, a book to read, or just someone to talk to. I remember her coming home exhausted after a long day at school, but she still made time to help me with my homework or listen to me when I was upset. My dad was more hands-on with the practical things—fixing things around the house, helping me with math problems, or just being there to support us in whatever way he could. They never made me feel like I had to be perfect or that I had to earn their love, but they always made it clear that they believed in me. I think that's why I ended up being pretty good at math and science, even though I didn't go to college. I always knew I had their support, and that gave me a sense of security that I carried with me into adulthood.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Erin Mccloud: My mom was a teacher, and her most important activities were planning lessons, grading papers, and making sure her students felt supported. She had a way of connecting with kids, and I remember how she would stay after school to help anyone who needed extra help. She believed that every child had potential, and she worked hard to bring that out in them. My dad worked in IT, so his duties were more about problem-solving and keeping systems running. He was really good at figuring things out, whether it was fixing a computer or helping me with math. He always said that if you could break something down into smaller parts, you could solve almost anything. I think that's why I ended up being pretty good at math and science—because he taught me to think that way. Both of them had their own kind of work, but what I remember most is how they balanced their jobs with being there for us. They never missed a school event, they always made time to talk to us, and they never made us feel like we had to be perfect. I think that's what gave me the confidence to believe in myself, even when I didn't have the same opportunities as some of my friends.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Erin Mccloud: My mom worked at a local elementary school, and my dad was employed by a mid-sized tech company in Tulsa. My mom's job was more than just teaching—she was a mentor, a guide, and sometimes even a friend to the kids in her class. She taught third grade, and I remember how she would come home with stories about the kids she was helping, whether it was a student who was struggling with reading or one who just needed someone to listen. She always said that teaching wasn't just about lessons—it was about shaping lives, and I think that's why she gave so much of herself to her students. My dad worked in IT support, which meant he spent a lot of time troubleshooting computers, setting up networks, and making sure everything ran smoothly for the company. He had a way of explaining things in simple terms, even when they were complicated, and I think that's why I ended up being pretty good at math and science. He always encouraged me to ask questions and to never be afraid of making mistakes. Both of them worked in different fields, but what I remember most is how they made their jobs matter—not just for themselves, but for the people around them.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Erin Mccloud: I hope that in a few years, my life is still rooted in the same place I've always called home—Tulsa, on Elm Street. I hope my kids are growing up in a neighborhood that still feels safe and full of community, just like it has for me. I hope they have more opportunities than I did, whether that means going to college or finding their own path in life. I also hope that I'm still here, still healthy, and still able to be there for them. I don't know if I'll ever have a traditional career or a big house, but I hope I'm still finding joy in the little things—the sound of my kids laughing, the smell of fresh vegetables from our garden, the quiet moments with my husband on the porch. I hope I'm still learning, still growing, and still being the kind of person who puts others first, even if it means sacrificing my own dreams. I don't know what the future holds, but I hope it's filled with love, connection, and the same sense of purpose that has carried me through every challenge I've faced so far.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Erin Mccloud: What I value the most in my life is the love and connection I have with my family. There's nothing more important to me than knowing that my kids feel safe, supported, and loved. I also value the sense of community here in Tulsa—knowing that my neighbors are like family, and that there's always someone to lean on when things get tough. I value the little things, too, like the sound of my kids laughing in the garden, the way my husband still holds my hand when we're walking, and the quiet moments when I can just sit on the porch and breathe. I don't have a lot of material things, but I have a life that's full of meaning, and that's what matters most to me.

Going through the interview questions from 41 to 45 made me reflect on how much my role as a homemaker and caregiver is both demanding and deeply meaningful. It reminded me that while I don't have a traditional job with a set schedule or benefits, the work I do every day is just as important, if not more so, than any career path I might have taken. I realized how much I rely on my husband's support and the community around me to help me manage the responsibilities of our household. It also made me think about how I've adapted to the unpredictability of my work, finding strength in the flexibility it offers, even though it comes with its own kind of pressure. I'm proud of the life I've built, even if it doesn't look like what I once imagined, and I'm grateful for the people who help me keep going every day.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of reflection and rediscovery. It's strange how much I've come to value the life I've built, even if it wasn't the one I originally imagined. I've spent so much time thinking about the choices I've made, the sacrifices I've made for my family, and the moments that shaped me. I've realized that while I didn't take the path of college or a traditional career, I've still built something meaningful with my family, my neighborhood, and the people I love. I've also come to understand that my worth isn't tied to a job title or a degree, but to the love, support, and connection I've created in my life. I'm proud of who I am, even if I didn't follow the same road as others. I've learned to find joy in the everyday moments, to be kinder to myself, and to appreciate the people who have supported me along the way. I may not have the same opportunities as some, but I've built a life filled with purpose, love, and gratitude. I'm grateful for this journey, and I'm ready to keep growing, one day at a time.
